intro: Boechera consanguinea, commonly known as the mountain rockcress, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine habitats, demonstrating a preference for well-drained soils and full sun. It has basal leaves that are usually lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs. Boechera consanguinea is also known for its ability to produce both self-compatible and self-incompatible seeds, contributing to its reproductive success in diverse environments.
